title: Which of the following US stock market indexes will perform worst between 31 January 2019 and 31 July 2019?
preds:
Initial Impression:
(no research yet) Off the cuff based on tech weakness.  That said, people are crazy and ignoring market fundamentals.  Facebook's recent fines have also already been levied and are theoretically priced in.  S+P and DJIA are popular IRA/401k bets and less likely to change hands than the russell and Nasdaq (though, of course, the major players are present in all of them).  Everybody is forecasting a rate cut this week, but if it doesn't go through tech (Nasdaq) will suffer.  Smaller stocks will get hit hard, so russel and dow are definitely still possibilities, but I'm mostly focusing on the big movers that drive markets.  We'll see what happens.  We're also coming up on an election cycle and everyone loves to hate big data right now, so if someone is foreced to break up, antitrist, etc, then nasdaq's gonna get hit hard.   << Of note, I'm just sifting through questions now for initial impressions - haven't done any research yet (and the crowd totally disagrees with me) >>

Russell underperforming the Dow Jones today further lowers the chances of a come-back. My Monte Carlo model continues to show a less than 100% chance that the Russell will end up the worst-performing but my model also does not account for the correlation between the indeces, which makes diverging performances (i.e. a strong Russell and a weak Dow) unlikely.

Current (July 26) performance ratios (from Day 1) are
DJ=1.09,  NASDAQ=1.14,  RU=1.05,  SP=1.12 With a few days to go and a performance ratio of almost half of that of the closest competitor, there is no chance that Russell can catch up.  I have to abandon the update model used in [1] which failed.  It is a bit late, ha! However it is interesting to point out that the baseline forecast for the performance ratios used in [2] are
DJ=1.09,  NASDAQ=1.14,  RU=1.10,  SP=1.08    based on statistics for mid-term election years. Performance ratios for DJ and NASDAQ this year are the same as the average mid-term years.  They are much better than non-midterm election years (which are DJ=1.03,  NASDAQ=1.02  RU=1.03,  SP=1.03). While my update model failed, it appears that the basic premise of better (significant) stock performance in mid-term election years wins another data point.  (I know, it is less than 20 data points since 1946, but still it is interesting and something to ponder about. )   I am sharing this information with @nigster, @Emil and @sreichau who participated in the original discussion in [2].  Thanks guys. [1]  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/831762
[2]  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/826512

Russel futures jumping  +18.   Points to a strong Monday... Russell needs 3 strong days to overtake dow. Dow futures flat. So while I don't' think Russell will catch, I'm positioning in case a strong monday... makes it possible. S&P +11.8%
Dow +8.6%
Nasdaq +10.1%
Russell 5.5% however russell only needs to get to 1629.9 to beat dow (at moment).
Thats 48 points over todays futures.    Russell is strongly dependent on liquidity and FOMB meeting.....

Whew...  3 ish more days like today and russell tops dow.   Double tops signalliing a possible breakout - and Russell more interest rate sensitive.  this could bloody well happen  - fed drops .50 russell will react more strongly.     I've been heavy on russell .. I'm going to average down on Dow for a day or so and see how the market trends Monday
It 26th of July and performances of above indexs can all be found on internet. No intention to cheat in this game. I just tried to get myself famiar with this BRIER Points system.

There's only one scenario that I can image which would propel the Dow below the Russell.  Boeing comprises nearly 10% of the DJIA.  Boeing stock has held up remarkably well in the face of the 737 MAX troubles.  If BA were to suddenly drop by 30% it would put the Dow in the same ballpark as the Russell, with regard to their gains since January 31.  This would seem to be a longshot, especially given that so little time is left.  So I'll leave the odds the the Russell will be the laggard at 93%.

Only 18 trading days remain until the close of this challenge.  The Dow is 2.61% ahead of the Russell index.  The S&P 500 and NASDAQ indices are 5.51% and 7.01% ahead of the Russell, respectively, since January 31.  The gaps could close, but it's less likely with each passing day.  So I've upped the odds that the Russell 2000 is the lagging index.

Update for the week ending 28 June: 
DJ: 25% (6.4% relative performance since Day 1) 
NASDAQ: 20% (10.0%) 
Russell: 38% (4.5%) 
SP500: 17% (8.8%) It is interesting to point out that in my last forecast for 7 June, the performance of the indices relative to Day 1 was much lower than now (by 2 to 4 percentage points), but the forecast probabilities of the worst performing index do not change much.
The Russell index still lags, but has closed the gap over the past couple of days.  Only two days ago I put the odds at 83% for the Russell.  That was too extreme, so I'm dialing it back to 59%.

Trading days remaining: 24 0.8%	Dow Jones (+6.2%)
0.3%	NASDAQ Composite (+8.3%)
98.9%	Russell 2000 (+1.4%)
0.0%	S&P 500 (+7.9%) Crowd: 26%, 14%, 45%, 15%.

The gap between the Dow and the Russell indices has continued to widen.  While the Russell could snap back, with only 5 weeks to go for the challenge it seems unlikely to close such a wide gap (4.85%).  What scenario could cause the Dow to crash that would not also affect the small cap Russell index?  Or what good news could cause the Russell to melt up significantly more that the Dow?  Likewise regarding the even wider gap to the NASDAQ and S&P 500.

The Russell 2000 is inherently less liquid than any of the other markets.  Fed draining reserve funds causes a decrease in liquidity, which will cause bigger swings in less liquid markets.  Fed ending its QE normalization would differentially help the russell, but not significantly I expect.
Damn, much too late with updating, too much happening IRL

Flight to safety in jittery times
Rumors of trade deal

Only 40 calendar days remain for this challenge, and only 27 trading days.  The NASDAQ has advanced 10.3% vs only 3.35% for the Russell.  That's nearly a 7% gap, which is highly unlikely to close.  So I'm putting the odds that the NASDAQ will be the laggard at 0%, and boosting the odds that the Russell remains behind at 71%.

As of this writing Dow +2.7%,  Russell +1.7%.  Russell outperforms in periods of economic retrenchment.  Dow in periods of continued growth.
The Russell has more turbulence.    So a lot of the answer will depend on where you think the economy is going:  steady: vote Russell to underperform.  Turbulent, vote Dow.

May 2019 analysis, my summary: Russell is likely to be absorbing some risky stocks: Uber, Lyft, Tesla. However, those particular ones aren't likely to crater before the forecast horizon. On the other hand Russel doesn't exercise the caution of the S&P in adding new companies.  Source: https://americanconsequences.com/blood-sucking-ipos/
General instability will, sooner rather than later take its toll on the overall markets.  Trade war with China will continue to hurt High Tech and Agri-business more than other industries

All of the market indices are weak today because of China trade concerns.  The Dow and the Russell have moved closer together.  I'm going to take some of "cafebedouin's" advice and do a little hedging.  I wrote about the benefits of hedging in a previous forecast/post of mine, but then failed to take my own advice.  I also did not calculate the risk/reward ratio for my selections.  My bad!  Shortcuts lead to bad outcomes. So now I'll put a few chips on the NASDAQ and S&P, while somewhat evening out my bets on the Dow and Russell.  I am still heavily favoring the Dow or the Russell to be the worst-performing index.

The crowd gives the Russell 2000 and the DJIA about equal chances of underperforming (37% and 36%).  Currently the Dow is lagging the other indices.  If there is a trade deal with China then the large Dow stocks could improve.  If the trade war gets out of hand the smaller Russell companies could outperform.  So with 80 days remaining it may come down to whether or not a trade deal gets done, and when. Since this challenge is not a binary choice it is difficult to get a low Brier score.  The crowd gives the S&P + NASDAQ a combined probability of 27%.  I've given them both zero probability, preferring to heavily weight the favorites.  This could backfire!  We'll see. For now I'm still betting that the relationship between the Dow and the Russell indices will reverse.
Trade risk, imo targets larger cap, international companies.
This is a small adjustment -- the DJIA has been the weakest index lately.  I'm still keeping the Russell as the favorite to win this challenge.

The indices are being 'pumped' by FAANGs and hitech IPO's, but this does not touch the valuations on smaller or non-tech companies. While the US economy is running  well, investors (who drive equity valuations) are swirling around the names like Uber but not smaller companies or other sectors. (I don't think this can last and i think a lot are bubbles, but you know what Keynes said about the irrationality of markets). The DJIA is a weird one, and why it still gets followed I don't know, it does not represent market activity.

With 96 Days remaining until July 31, here are the "box scores": NASDAQ -- +11.87% 
S&P 500 -- +8.72% 
Dow Jones Ind -- +6.17% 
Russell 2000 -- +6.16% The top ten Dow stocks make up nearly 53% of the index, while the bottom ten comprise less than 16%.  Boeing has the heaviest weight at 9.8%, and 3M is seventh at 4.9%.  MMM got clobbered this week after announcing earnings, and Boeing is struggling with the 737 Max problems.  So the DJIA could still be the worst performer if the small cap index picks up.  This week I'm reducing the chances for the S&P and NASDAQ to zero, and putting those percentage points on the Russell 2000 and DJIA.

1)Find out historical performance for the indexes during all 104 days periods(remaining time to  the deadline).
2)Adjust values for current performance for each index from 31-Jan-19 to current date to get simulated distribution of future outcomes based on historical record.
3)Calculate the frequencies.

As of 4-18-19 the index gains since January 31st are as follows: NASDAQ -- +9.84%
S&P 500 -- +7.43%
Dow Jones Ind -- +6.24%
Russell 2000 -- +4.42% A little over 100 days remain for this challenge.  Most economists seem to agree that we are in the late stages of the business cycle.  Small cap stocks, i.e., Russell 2000, generally do best early in the cycle.  Large cap stocks outperform (S&P and Dow) later in the cycle.  And tech stocks have been especially strong this year (NASDAQ). Based on these trends, and the fact that the Russell has lagged for most of the past 3 months, I'm increasing the probability that the Russell will remain the laggard index to 57%.
Tech growth is difficult, prices are already high.  A lot of money keeps flowing in blue chips.

The smaller the diversity, (DOW being least diversified) the larger the downside risk. NASDAQ is tech-heavy, one strong common cyberthreat could weigh very heavily on it, otherwise, would rate it stronger.
Several DJIA heavyweights likely to take massive hits [uppercuts] to their share prices...

The markets tanked today, with the Russell 2000 hit especially hard (up only 0.43% since Jan 31).  The small cap index is the most volatile, and one would expect it to move the fastest and furthest in either direction.  That makes it a wild card, but right now it is way behind the other indices.  The NASDAQ is ahead (+4.96%), followed by the S&P (+3.57%).  The Dow is in the middle (+2.01%).  I am splitting my bet between the Dow and the Russell.
updated since Nasdaq up 6%, sp500 up 4.5%, and DJIA and Russell 2000 only up 3%

Rankings to date: DJIA -- +3.40%*
NASDAQ -- 5.59%
Russell 2000 -- 3.61%
SPY 500 -- 4.38% The Dow is lagging, in part due to Boeing's 737 MAX troubles.  Boeing is the highest priced stock in the DJIA, so it has the highest weighting.  A key question is just how long Boeing's problems will persist.  I'm guessing the stock will not simply bounce back.  Small cap stocks are also lagging, with the Russell 2000 less than a quarter point ahead of the Dow. The NASDAQ is clearly ahead as tech stocks have recovered.  The semiconductor segment has been especially strong.  There is a lot of time left, so things could change, but I'm staying with the S&P as a low probability of underperforming.  But I'm reducing the chance of underperformance for the NASDAQ, and making the Dow and the Russell the favorites to underperform.  This is pretty close to the crowd forecast.
Agreeing with nigster,  weighting against the dow due to the companies comprising; uncomfortable with Nasdaq due to volatility and trade sanctions.

I will update the forecast every week.  I believe that daily updates are not necessary since daily movements of the market are pretty random. In this model for updating the forecast, the 6-month rise rates for the indices in midterm years [1] are assumed to hold linearly over time.  The market rises from the update day to the end (31 July) are obtained by linearly interpolating the 6-month rise.  For example, from half way into the forecasting period to the end, the rises are half of the 6-month rises.  These interpolated rises, together with their standard deviations are used in Monte Carlo simulations to obtain performance ratios from the update day to the end (31 July).  The current (at the update day) performance ratios are added to the Monte Carlo simulation results.  The worst performing indices are then identified and their probabilities computed (similar to what was done in the baseline case [1]). Update for 1 March (29 days from start of the forecast period):
DJ, NASDAQ, R2000, SP500:   27, 15, 26, 32.   Note that the forecasts for the 6-month period (baseline [1]) are 24, 17, 28 and 31, not that different from the updated forecast about 1 month later). For comparison, if non-midterm results were used, the forecasts are
24, 27, 23 and 26. Rationale:
While this update model assumes the 6-month rise rates, the incorporation of the current (at update day) performance ratios acts as an insurance policy.  I have contemplated daily updates but feel that they just add “noise” in the forecast, and they will not help much in enhancing the forecast scores.   Of course there is a question of whether the rise rates behave linearly.  Examination of the 12-month and 6-month rise rates suggests that this assumption is reasonable.   [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/831325

- R2000 has been the worst performing of these indices for all 6-month periods since the period ending 1st Oct 2018.
- I also looked at how often each of these indices was the worst-performing or within 2% of the worst-performing (to hopefully account for volatility when it is a close race) for all 6-month periods since the period ending 31st July 2018, result: DJIA: 24%, Nasdaq: 4% R2000: 59%, S&P500: 13%. So this also points to R2000, like the point above. Nevertheless I am giving Nasdaq the second highest probability, because Nasdaq and R2000 are currently the two indices performing worst when looking at a 6 month sliding window. 
- The ratio of current value/value at end of 31 Jan 2019 sees R2000 being the best performing though (at a ratio of 1.06), with the others very close together (DJIA 1.041, Nasdaq 1.043, S&P 1.037)

This is an update from my original forecast based on looking for patterns in the stock indices after midterm elections.  Thanks to @Emil @nigster and @sreichau for interesting and useful discussions.  You can read all the discussions in [1]. There are two approaches to forecasting the challenge question, based on different assumptions/principles.  One is based on the market being random. This is used by @Emil in the Monte Carlo simulations, and by @nigster in his data-driven and data assimilation model.  The other is based on decipherable patterns in the market, used here and @sreichau.   Analyses have shown that in some situations, there are patterns in the stock market.   Since 1946, the US stock market went higher in next 12 months after each of the 18 midterm elections [2].  It so happened that the 6-month period in this challenge question is between 3 to 9 months after a midterm election.  So is there a pattern in the historical data that we can use to forecast this question? Daily market close data for all 4 indices between 1990 and 2018 from the Yahoo Finance webpage were analyzed.  The objectives of the analysis are to 
1.	How did the markets do 12 months after midterm elections and how did they compare with non-midterm election years?
2.	Answer the same questions as in 1, but for a shorter period of 6 months since the forecast question deals with this shorter period.
3.	Answer the same questions for a 6-month period spanning 3 to 9 months after 1 November (the specific period in the forecast question) for midterm and non-midterm years.
Note that comparing midterm and non-midterm results is critical to the validity in using the midterm patterns in the forecast, as pointed out correctly by @Emil and @sreichau.

A performance ratio for each index (end index divided by start index) for a given period (defined in questions 1-3) is calculated.  For convenience, 1 November is chosen to be the start date for midterm years.  The same date is also used for non-midterm years.  To make the analysis more robust (i.e. make it less dependent on the exact dates chosen), additional performance ratios for each index are calculated by moving the start dates up and down by one month resulting in 46 cases for each year analyzed.  In this dataset, there are 7 midterm years (excluding the last one in 2018) and 21 non-midterm years. Results: The mean performance ratios and their standard errors (in parentheses) for the indices are listed in the order of DJ, NASDAQ, Russell 2000 and SP500. 12-month period (Question 1): 
Midterm years:              1.1521 (0.0055); 1.3386 (0.0134), 1.1897 (0.0100), 1.1547 (0.0058)
Non-midterm years:     1.0769 (0.0046); 1.0828 (0.0069); 1.0841 (0.0055); 1.0731 (0.0051) Interestingly the market rose in 12 months independent of whether it is a midterm year or not.  However, the rise in midterm years are significantly higher (by about a factor of two or more) than in non-midterm years.  This confirms the article [2] and what @sreichau found for non-midterm years.  How about 6-month period results? 6-month period (Question 2) (from November to March the following year):  Midterm years:          1.1148 (0.0042);  1.1987 (0.0093);  1.1488 (0.0067); 1.1214 (0.0044)
Non-midterm years;  1.0621 (0.0024);  1.0495 (0.0047);  1.0702 (0.0032);  1.0501 (0.0027) The market again rose for the 6-month periods albeit the rises are smaller than the 12-month periods for midterm years.  However, there is not much difference between the 6-month and 12-months periods for the non-midterm years.   Special periods (in the challenge question):  Midterm years:           1.0921 (0.0048); 1.1441 (0.0069); 1.1021 (0.0068);  1.0777 (0.0046)
Non-midterm years:   1.0270 (0.0027); 1.0171 (0.0044); 1.0250 (0.0033); 1.0295 (0.0031) The market rose again for the special 6-month periods.  However, while the rise is 8-14 percent for the midterm years, it is only 2-3 percent for non-midterm years.   The 95% confidence limits are mean +/- 2 times the standard error.  The above analysis shows that the market rise in midterm years are different from non-midterm years for both 12-month, 6-month and the special 6-month periods.   To forecast the worst performing index in this question, the analysis results in the midterm years were used.  Monte Carlo simulations using the mean performance ratios of the indices and their standard deviations were performed.  The worst performing indices in the simulations were identified and their percentages were calculated.  The results are:
DJ, NASDAQ, R2000, SP500:   
30%, 12%, 30%, 28% This is the baseline forecast.  Just for fun, the worst performing indices in non-midterm years are
23%, 29%, 24% and 24%. I will address how to update the forecasts in a different post. [1]  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/826512
[2] https://www.forbes.com/sites/stephenmcbride1/2018/11/02/ive-studied-stocks-after-every-midterm-election-since-world-war-ii-what-i-found-will-shock-you/#57c2b9383c20

Using rough numbers for the Feb 15 market close: the Russell 2000 is up the most (+4.7%), followed by the DJIA (+3.5%); the S&P 500 is up 2.65%, and the NASDAQ is up 2.6%.  Things could of course change, but the Russell is ahead for now. The Russell is broad with respect to industries included, but is limited to small capitalization companies.  As such it has less international exposure than the other indices.  A weakening global economy may favor the Russell. 
 The NASDAQ is not based on anything other the trading exchange; it has a concentration in technology, which means growth. The S&P 500 is the broadest index by far.  It includes 500 companies and is capitalization weighted.  The Dow is price weighted, so you have to look at the composition of the index to see what you are buying.  Although the Dow includes 30 very large blue chip companies, nearly 54% consists of only 10 companies -- Boeing, United Health, 3M, Goldman Sachs, Home Depot, MacDonald's, Apple, Visa, IBM and Caterpillar.  The S&P outperforms the Dow more often than not.  Notice that Apple has less than half the weight of Boeing in the Dow, whereas it has more than three times the weighting in the S&P 500. I have given the highest probability of underperformance to the most concentrated indices, with an eye towards year to date performance and international exposure.

I have a 65% odds of recession orientation and 35% or expansion orientation with Russell 2000 riskiest, then Nasdaq, then sp500, then Dow Jones. Although we are reaching the end of an economic cycle, due to the FED dovish remarks in the past month I think they may soften the rate increases and that can increase the confidence of the markets. Even if they increase the rates, it can serve as moral suasion that signals to the markets that the economy is strong and healthy. The big problem here is the US-China trade war, if it escalates, we may face a bear market in the coming months. I believe it is more likely that this will not happen in the next couple of months but I am not very confident in it given the US president volatility. Therefore, I think we will have a bullish market in the next 6 months and that the SP500 will lag the other more volatile indices, just for Beta reasons.

This challenge question is to forecast the relative performance of 4 US stock market indices in a designated 6 month period (31 January 2019 to 31 July 2019).  If the markets and the indices were truly random, the probability of being the worst performer would be 25% for each of the indices.  But are they random?  Or do historical data show patterns that we can use for forecasting this question?   Analyses have shown that in some situations, there are patterns in the stock market.   Since 1946, the US stock market went higher in next 12 months after each of the 18 midterm elections [1].  This consistent rise after a midterm election is amazing and robust as it happened regardless of the ruling party and winning party in the midterm.  These 70 plus years spanned over booms and recessions too.  You can read the many hypotheses for the rising market after the midterms in the same article [1].   With this revelation in mind, the period in the forecast question has a special focus.  Instead of analysis ALL the historical data, I focus on the data around midterm elections.  Specifically I focused on the historical data in the 6 month period (January to July) starting from 3 months after a midterm election (January).  I looked for historical patterns that can help the forecast for this special period.  (Of course I understand that “past performances do not guarantee future results”.)  Weekly closing values of the four indices from 1990 to present were obtained from the Yahoo Finance webpage for the analysis.  The data cover 7 midterm elections (excluding the last one in 2018).   Sure enough, each of the indices was higher 12 months after all of the 7 midterm elections.  This is a nice consistency check on the pattern described in the article [1]. Next I analyzed the data for time period in the question.  A performance ratio for each index at 3 months (31 January) and 9 months (31 July) after a midterm election is computed by dividing the latter by the former.  To make the analysis more robust (i.e. make it less dependent on the exact dates chosen), I also calculated additional performance ratios for each index by moving the dates up and down by 1 week and 2 weeks, resulting in 5 6-month periods for each midterm election, and a total of 35 periods for the 7 midterm elections analyzed.   The worst performance index in each period is counted.  The number of times that an index being the worst performer are:
DJ: 14,  NASDAQ: 1, R2000: 12, SP500:8  and resulting in 40%, 3%, 34% and 23%, respectively.  (One can choose to analyze the daily closing values instead of the weekly values used here, but I suspect that this pattern will survive). It will be interesting to see the results when ALL the historical data were analyzed (instead of focusing on the midterm elections in here). I will use the above results in my forecast, fully realizing that “past performances do not guarantee future results”.  Many people are arguing that this midterm is different from Trump. But is it?  The historical results are rather robust, spanning booms and busts, recessions and different presidents and parties in power.  We will see. [1] https://www.forbes.com/sites/stephenmcbride1/2018/11/02/ive-studied-stocks-after-every-midterm-election-since-world-war-ii-what-i-found-will-shock-you/#57c2b9383c20

The growth leadership evident in most markets in recent quarters reversed dramatically, led by a significant sell-off in technology. The NASDAQ is in a bear market and this has already gone on far longer than the shortest one on record, At best it will be medium in duration or longer. On 30 August 2018, the NASDAQ Composite entered its first bear market since the 2007-2009 recession; as of 3 January 2019 this bear market is ongoing with the index down 21%. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASDAQ_Composite Nasdaq has endured 10 previous bear markets since it was launched in February 1971. Six of them lasted a year or longer. In three of them the index lost more than half its value. If this one bears any resemblance to its predecessors, investors should expect another eight to nine months of declines and their losses to deepen significantly from here. Some key facts of past Nasdaq bear markets: * On average, they have featured a decline of 39.74 percent over 248 trading days, roughly the length of a calendar year. * The median decline has been 32.25 percent over 266 trading days. * The great dot-com bust of the early part of the century still stands as the index’s biggest and longest-lasting collapse. Nasdaq lost a gut-wrenching 77.93 percent over 674 trading days between March 2000 and October 2002. * The most mild bear market saw a decline of 20.37 percent over 44 days between Sept. 13, 1978, and Nov. 14, 1978. * The shortest one lasted just 34 days from Feb. 8, 1980, to March 27, 1980. The index fell 24.91 percent in that span. * Over its nearly 48 years in existence, Nasdaq has spent roughly 20 percent of the time - more than 2,500 trading days - in bear market territory. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-stocks-nasdaq-bears-factbox/factbox-past-nasdaq-bear-markets-lasted-long-and-cut-deep-idUSKCN1OK2AQ

Extended thinking from https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/824258 to look at the past 20 years, this gives:
Dow 35, NASDAQ 30, Russell 20, S&P 15
Last 10 years: 40,10,30,20 Interestingly NASDAQ was the worst performer in only one out of the last 10 years (2016), and that year was very close with DJIA, NASDAQ and S&P almost in a three-way tie. However, in the 10 years prior to that, NASDAQ was the worst performer in 5 of those years. Question is: has something fundamentally changed that allows tech  companies to build more sustainable businesses (or at least well-performing stocks) or is this just another bubble like the early 2000s? I am not sure, so I am going to increase the weight of recent performance by taking the average of the frequencies from the last 20 and the last 10 years.

Outside view: I took daily data for the past 10 years from [1] and calculated 6-month returns, which provides a total of 2396 historical data points. For each of those instances, I found the worst performer and then estimated historical base rates for each index. Results: 35, 11, 38, 16.  Inside view: NASDAQ may underperform compared to the historical base rate as tech companies are seeing slow down in earnings and have been contributing less to the performance of broader indexes such as S&P 500. [2]. I am therefore raising NASDAQ chances. I am choosing to reallocate toward S&P 500 for now. [2] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/04/business/dealbook/tech-chips-slowdown.html

2015 Dow

2017 Russell 2000
2018 Dow Taking this as the baseline for now, but giving a slight hedge to Nasdaq. More insight could come from understanding the composition of the indices better and the conditions that are correlated to their respective performances. Also, looking at more historical data could help.
